overview.business_description: Global independent convenience retailer operating 6,000+ fuel forecourt sites with convenience stores across multiple countries. Founded by Mohsin & Zuber Issa brothers. Operates fuel retail, convenience stores, and foodservice franchises (Starbucks, KFC, Burger King, etc.).
business_positives: Active deleveraging through strategic asset sales
Bonds trading above par (108) despite high coupons
Experienced Issa brothers + TDR Capital sponsorship
overview.fatal_flaw: EXPENSIVE capital structure with 11-12% coupon notes. Feb 2028 TLB maturity wall of ~$3.2bn. 2Q25 EBITDA dipped 1.1% YoY. Private company with limited transparency. Related party complexity (Asda, Issa brothers).
overview.ownership: TDR Capital LLP (50%) + Issa Brothers (Mohsin & Zuber). Private company.
overview.recent_news: 2Q25 underlying EBITDA dipped 1.1% YoY to USD 270m. Sold Australian business to Ampol (EUR 615m, Aug 2025). Sold Italian business (EUR 425m, Aug 2025). Priced EUR 1.525bn TLB at E+387.5bps (Jul 2025). Weighing Starbucks franchise sale for Costa Coffee bid.

debt_capitalization.instrument: EUR 1641m Term Loan B First Lien
USD 1700m Term Loan B First Lien

credit_opinion.summary: EG Group is a B3/B- convenience/forecourt operator actively deleveraging through asset sales. The capital structure is EXPENSIVE (11-12% notes) but bonds trading at 108+ (above par) shows market confidence in the asset sales strategy. TLBs near par at 100-101. Main concern is the Feb 2028 TLB maturity wall (~$3.2bn) and Nov 2028 notes (~$2.1bn). Distress score of 10 is reasonable. The Issa brothers and TDR Capital are experienced but there's complexity with related party transactions (Asda).
key_risks: Feb 2028 TLB maturity wall (~$3.2bn) - major refinancing need
EXPENSIVE capital structure (11-12% notes, E+450bps TLBs)
Related party complexity (Issa brothers own Asda too)
key_catalysts: Asset sale proceeds applied to debt reduction
Potential Costa Coffee acquisition could add scale

distress_indicators.trading_signals: Bonds at 108+ (well above par) despite 11-12% coupons - market pricing successful deleveraging. TLBs at 100-101. YTW 7.7-8.5% reflects B3/B- risk but not distress.
